mn106:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.
mn106:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
mn106:2.1: “Mendicants, sensual pleasures are impermanent, hollow, false, and deceptive.
mn106:2.2: This is made by illusion, mendicants, lamented by fools.
mn106:2.3: Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:2.4: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:2.5: both of these are Māra’s dominion, Māra’s domain, Māra’s lair, and Māra’s range.
mn106:2.6: They conduce to bad, unskillful notions such as desire, ill will, and aggression.
mn106:2.7: And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.
mn106:3.1: A noble disciple reflects on this:
mn106:3.2: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:3.3: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:3.4: both of these are Māra’s dominion, Māra’s domain, Māra’s lair, and Māra’s range.
mn106:3.5: They conduce to bad, unskillful notions such as desire, ill will, and aggression.
mn106:3.6: And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.
mn106:3.7: Why don’t I meditate with an abundant, expansive heart, having mastered the world and stabilized the mind?
mn106:3.8: Then I will have no more bad, unskillful notions such as desire, ill will, and aggression.
mn106:3.9: And by giving them up my mind, no longer limited, will become limitless and well developed.’
mn106:3.10: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:3.11: Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:3.12: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the imperturbable.
mn106:3.13: This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.
mn106:4.2: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:4.3: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:4.4: whatever form there is, all form is the four principal states, or form derived from the four principal states.’
mn106:4.5: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:4.6: Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:4.7: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the imperturbable.
mn106:4.8: This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.
mn106:5.2: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:5.3: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:5.4: visions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:5.5: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come;
mn106:5.7: And what’s impermanent is not worth approving, welcoming, or clinging to.’
mn106:5.8: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:5.9: Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:5.10: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the imperturbable.
mn106:5.11: This is said to be the third way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.
mn106:6.2: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:6.3: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:6.4: visions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:6.5: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:6.8: Where they cease without anything left over, that is peaceful, that is sublime,
mn106:6.10: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:6.11: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:6.12: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
mn106:6.13: This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.
mn106:7.1: Furthermore, a noble disciple has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
mn106:7.2: ‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’
mn106:7.3: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:7.4: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:7.5: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
mn106:7.6: This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.
mn106:8.2: ‘I don’t belong to anyone anywhere! And nothing belongs to me anywhere!’
mn106:8.3: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:8.4: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:8.5: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
mn106:8.6: This is said to be the third way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.
mn106:9.2: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:9.3: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:9.4: visions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:9.5: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:9.6: perceptions of the imperturbable, and perceptions of the dimension of nothingness;
mn106:9.8: Where they cease without anything left over, that is peaceful, that is sublime,
mn106:9.9: namely the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
mn106:9.10: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
mn106:9.11: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception now, or are freed by wisdom.
mn106:9.12: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn106:9.13: This is said to be the way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”
mn106:10.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
mn106:10.2: “Sir, take a mendicant who practices like this:
mn106:10.3: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
mn106:10.4: In this way they gain equanimity.
mn106:10.5: Would that mendicant become extinguished or not?”
mn106:10.6: “One such mendicant might become extinguished, Ānanda, while another might not.”
mn106:10.7: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for this?”
mn106:10.8: “Ānanda, take a mendicant who practices like this:
mn106:10.9: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
mn106:10.10: In this way they gain equanimity.
mn106:10.11: They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to that equanimity.
mn106:10.12: Their consciousness has that as support and fuel for grasping.
mn106:10.13: A mendicant with fuel for grasping does not become extinguished.”
mn106:11.1: “But sir, what is that mendicant grasping?”
mn106:11.2: “The dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”
mn106:11.3: “Sir, it seems that mendicant is grasping the best thing to grasp!”
mn106:11.5: For the best thing to grasp is
mn106:11.6: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn106:12.1: Take a mendicant who practices like this:
mn106:12.2: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
mn106:12.3: In this way they gain equanimity.
mn106:12.4: They don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to that equanimity.
mn106:12.5: So their consciousness doesn’t have that as support and fuel for grasping.
mn106:12.6: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.”
mn106:13.2: It seems the Buddha has explained to us how to cross over the flood by relying on one support or another.
mn106:13.3: But sir, what is noble liberation?”
mn106:13.4: “Ānanda, it’s when a noble disciple reflects like this:
mn106:13.5: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:13.6: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:13.7: visions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:13.8: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come,
mn106:13.9: perceptions of the imperturbable, perceptions of the dimension of nothingness, perceptions of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception;
mn106:13.10: that is substantial reality as far as substantial reality extends.
mn106:13.11: But this is freedom from death, namely the liberation of the mind through not grasping.
mn106:14.1: So, Ānanda, I have taught the ways of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable, the dimension of nothingness, and the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. I have taught how to cross the flood by relying on one support or another, and I have taught noble liberation.
mn106:15.1: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
mn106:15.2: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
mn106:15.3: That is what the Buddha said.
mn106:15.4: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
